articles.title: Why Claude Code Subagents Waste 50K Tokens Per Turn (And How to Fix It)
articles.description: If you use Claude Code with plugins or MCP servers and spawn subagents (the Task tool), you might be burning through your token quota much faster than expected. Here's why, and a concrete fix. The Problem When Claude Code spawns a subagent via the Task tool, each subprocess is a fresh claude CLI pro
articles.content: If you use Claude Code with plugins or MCP servers and spawn subagents (the Task tool), you might be burning through your token quota much faster than expected. Here's why, and a concrete fix. The Problem When Claude Code spawns a subagent via the Task tool, each subprocess is a fresh claude CLI process. That process inherits your entire global configuration : ~/CLAUDE.md (your project instructions) All enabled plugins and their skills Every MCP server's tool descriptions User-level settings fro
articles.author: Jaehoon Jung

articles.title: The Stop Killing Games campaign will set up NGOs in the EU and US
articles.description: The Stop Killing Games campaign is evolving into more than just a movement. In a YouTube video , the campaign's creator, Ross Scott, explained that organizers are planning to establish two non-governmental organizations, one for the European Union and another for the US. According to Scott, thes
articles.content: The Stop Killing Games campaign is evolving into more than just a movement. In a YouTube video , the campaign's creator, Ross Scott, explained that organizers are planning to establish two non-governmental organizations, one for the European Union and another for the US. According to Scott, these NGOs would allow for "long-term counter lobbying" when publishers end support for certain video games. "Let me start off by saying I think we're going to win this, namely the problem of publishe
articles.author: Jackson Chen

articles.title: NASA says it needs to haul the Artemis II rocket back to the hangar for repairs
articles.description: "Accessing and remediating any of these issues can only be performed in the VAB."
articles.content: A day after NASA officials expressed optimism that they could be ready to launch the Artemis II mission around the Moon next month, the space agency's administrator announced Saturday that a new problem will require the removal of the rocket from its launch pad in Florida. The latest issue appeared Friday evening, when data showed an interruption in helium flow into the upper stage of the Space Launch System rocket, NASA Administrator Jared Isaacman wrote in a post on X . Isaacman posted a more

articles.content: Fun vibes. Okay-ish photos. | Photo: Antonio G. Di Benedetto / The Verge There's been a surge of interest over the last few years in inexpensive digital cameras. Younger folks are snapping up old point-and-shoots because they view the aesthetic as more authentic and more appealing than smartphone images. Companies are even rereleasing old tech at new prices . articles.title: Have we leapt into commercial genetic testing without understanding it?
articles.description: A new book argues that tests might reshape human diversity even if they don't work.
articles.content: Daphne O. Martschenko and Sam Trejo both want to make the world a better, fairer, more equitable place. But they disagree on whether studying social genomics—elucidating any potential genetic contributions to behaviors ranging from mental illnesses to educational attainment to political affiliation—can help achieve this goal. Martschenko’s argument is largely that genetic research and data have almost always been used thus far as a justification to further entrench extant social inequalities. Bu
articles.author: Diana Gitig

articles.title: Quantonation’s double-sized second fund shows quantum still has believers
articles.description: Quantonation Ventures, a venture firm investing in quantum and physics-based startups, has closed its oversubscribed second fund at €220 million, or approximately $260 million. That’s more than twice the size of its inaugural fund, and comes in addition to other signals that the quantum winter isn’t
articles.content: Quantonation Ventures, a venture firm investing in quantum and physics-based startups, has closed its oversubscribed second fund at €220 million, or approximately $260 million. That’s more than twice the size of its inaugural fund, and comes in addition to other signals that the quantum winter isn’t coming yet.

articles.title: Study shows how rocket launches pollute the atmosphere
articles.description: Is the global atmospheric commons destined to be an industrial waste dumping ground?
articles.content: New research published Thursday bolsters growing concerns that a handful of companies and countries are using the global atmospheric commons as a dumping ground for potentially toxic and climate-altering industrial waste byproducts from loosely regulated commercial space flights. The new study analyzed a plume of pollution trailing part of a Falcon rocket that crashed through the upper atmosphere on Feb. 19, 2025, after SpaceX lost control of its reentry. The rocket was launched earlier that mon
articles.author: Bob Berwyn, Inside Climate News

articles.title: How I Built a System That Tracks 900,000 Real-Time Events Per Day
articles.description: A few months ago I started building a system to collect and analyze real-time event data. What began as a small experiment quickly grew into something much larger. The system now processes roughly 900,000 new records per day and has accumulated over 7 million total events so far. The biggest challen
articles.content: A few months ago I started building a system to collect and analyze real-time event data. What began as a small experiment quickly grew into something much larger. The system now processes roughly 900,000 new records per day and has accumulated over 7 million total events so far. The biggest challenge wasn’t collecting the data. It was making sure the system could continue scaling without slowing down. I chose PostgreSQL as the primary database because of its reliability and performance at scale
articles.author: Spindex

articles.title: This magazine plays Tetris — here’s how
articles.description: Tetris has been immortalized in a playable McDonald's plastic chicken nugget, a playable fake 7-Eleven Slurpee cup, and a playable wristwatch. But the most intriguing way to play Tetris yet is encased in paper. Last year the Tetris Company partnered with Red Bull for a gaming tournament that culmina
articles.content: The world’s first playable gaming magazine? Tetris has been immortalized in a playable McDonald's plastic chicken nugget , a playable fake 7-Eleven Slurpee cup , and a playable wristwatch . But the most intriguing way to play Tetris yet is encased in paper. Last year the Tetris Company partnered with Red Bull for a gaming tournament that culminated in the 150-meter-tall Dubai Frame landmark being turned into the world's largest playable Tetris installation using over 2,000 drones that functioned

articles.description: Apple’s satellite features were originally designed for emergencies, allowing iPhone users to contact emergency services when cellular and Wi-Fi coverage is unavailable. articles.content: Apple’s satellite features were originally designed for emergencies, allowing iPhone users to contact emergency services when cellular and Wi-Fi coverage is unavailable. With recent versions of iOS, Apple has expanded those capabilities to include sending and receiving messages via satellite. This makes it possible to stay in touch with friends and family from remote locations where traditional networks do not reach, such as hiking trails, rural areas or offshore locations. articles.title: Dinosaur eggshells can reveal the age of other fossils
articles.description: Like rocks, egg shells can trap isotopes, allowing us to use them to date samples.
articles.content: When dinosaur fossils surface at a site, it is often not possible to tell how many millions of years ago their bones were buried. While the different strata of sedimentary rock represent periods of geologic history frozen in time, accurately dating them or the fossils trapped within them has frequently proven to be frustrating. Fossilized bones and teeth have been dated with some success before, but that success is inconsistent and depends on the specimens. Both fossilization and the process of
articles.author: Elizabeth Rayne
